     140             : // TagHelper gets the given sentinel tag value for the given type T. This has to

     147             : // In the case where T != U, we continue recursion.

     149             : struct TagHelper<Tag, N, T, U, Next, false>

     152             : };
     153             : 
     154             : // In the case where T == U, return the tag number.

     156             : struct TagHelper<Tag, N, T, U, Next, true>
     157             : {
     158             :   static Tag tag() { return Tag(N); }

     161             : // The VariantImplementation template provides the guts of mozilla::Variant.  We
     162             : // create a VariantImplementation for each T in Ts... which handles
     163             : // construction, destruction, etc for when the Variant's type is T.  If the
     164             : // Variant's type isn't T, it punts the request on to the next
     165             : // VariantImplementation.
     166             : 
     167             : template<typename Tag, size_t N, typename... Ts>
     168             : struct VariantImplementation;

     176             :     static_assert(mozilla::IsSame<T, U>::value,
     177             :                   "mozilla::Variant: tag: bad type!");
     178             :     return Tag(N);
     179             :   }

     316             : } // namespace detail
     317             : 
     318             : /**
     319             :  * # mozilla::Variant
     320             :  *
     321             :  * A variant / tagged union / heterogenous disjoint union / sum-type template
     322             :  * class. Similar in concept to (but not derived from) `boost::variant`.
     323             :  *
     324             :  * Sometimes, you may wish to use a C union with non-POD types. However, this is
     325             :  * forbidden in C++ because it is not clear which type in the union should have
     326             :  * its constructor and destructor run on creation and deletion
     327             :  * respectively. This is the problem that `mozilla::Variant` solves.
     328             :  *
     329             :  * ## Usage
     330             :  *
     331             :  * A `mozilla::Variant` instance is constructed (via move or copy) from one of
     332             :  * its variant types (ignoring const and references). It does *not* support
     333             :  * construction from subclasses of variant types or types that coerce to one of
     334             :  * the variant types.
     335             :  *
     336             :  *     Variant<char, uint32_t> v1('a');
     337             :  *     Variant<UniquePtr<A>, B, C> v2(MakeUnique<A>());
     338             :  *
     339             :  * Because specifying the full type of a Variant value is often verbose,
     340             :  * AsVariant() can be used to construct a Variant value using type inference in
     341             :  * contexts such as expressions or when returning values from functions. Because
     342             :  * AsVariant() must copy or move the value into a temporary and this cannot
     343             :  * necessarily be elided by the compiler, it's mostly appropriate only for use
     344             :  * with primitive or very small types.
     345             :  *
     346             :  *
     347             :  *     Variant<char, uint32_t> Foo() { return AsVariant('x'); }
     348             :  *     // ...
     349             :  *     Variant<char, uint32_t> v1 = Foo();  // v1 holds char('x').
     350             :  *
     351             :  * All access to the contained value goes through type-safe accessors.
     352             :  *
     353             :  *     void
     354             :  *     Foo(Variant<A, B, C> v)
     355             :  *     {
     356             :  *       if (v.is<A>()) {
     357             :  *         A& ref = v.as<A>();
     358             :  *         ...
     359             :  *       } else {
     360             :  *         ...
     361             :  *       }
     362             :  *     }
     363             :  *
     364             :  * Attempting to use the contained value as type `T1` when the `Variant`
     365             :  * instance contains a value of type `T2` causes an assertion failure.
     366             :  *
     367             :  *     A a;
     368             :  *     Variant<A, B, C> v(a);
     369             :  *     v.as<B>(); // <--- Assertion failure!
     370             :  *
     371             :  * Trying to use a `Variant<Ts...>` instance as some type `U` that is not a
     372             :  * member of the set of `Ts...` is a compiler error.
     373             :  *
     374             :  *     A a;
     375             :  *     Variant<A, B, C> v(a);
     376             :  *     v.as<SomeRandomType>(); // <--- Compiler error!
     377             :  *
     378             :  * Additionally, you can turn a `Variant` that `is<T>` into a `T` by moving it
     379             :  * out of the containing `Variant` instance with the `extract<T>` method:
     380             :  *
     381             :  *     Variant<UniquePtr<A>, B, C> v(MakeUnique<A>());
     382             :  *     auto ptr = v.extract<UniquePtr<A>>();
     383             :  *
     384             :  * Finally, you can exhaustively match on the contained variant and branch into
     385             :  * different code paths depending which type is contained. This is preferred to
     386             :  * manually checking every variant type T with is<T>() because it provides
     387             :  * compile-time checking that you handled every type, rather than runtime
     388             :  * assertion failures.
     389             :  *
     390             :  *     // Bad!
     391             :  *     char* foo(Variant<A, B, C, D>& v) {
     392             :  *       if (v.is<A>()) {
     393             :  *         return ...;
     394             :  *       } else if (v.is<B>()) {
     395             :  *         return ...;
     396             :  *       } else {
     397             :  *         return doSomething(v.as<C>()); // Forgot about case D!
     398             :  *       }
     399             :  *     }
     400             :  *
     401             :  *     // Good!
     402             :  *     struct FooMatcher
     403             :  *     {
     404             :  *       // The return type of all matchers must be identical.
     405             :  *       char* match(A& a) { ... }
     406             :  *       char* match(B& b) { ... }
     407             :  *       char* match(C& c) { ... }
     408             :  *       char* match(D& d) { ... } // Compile-time error to forget D!
     409             :  *     }
     410             :  *     char* foo(Variant<A, B, C, D>& v) {
     411             :  *       return v.match(FooMatcher());
     412             :  *     }
     413             :  *
     414             :  * ## Examples
     415             :  *
     416             :  * A tree is either an empty leaf, or a node with a value and two children:
     417             :  *
     418             :  *     struct Leaf { };
     419             :  *
     420             :  *     template<typename T>
     421             :  *     struct Node
     422             :  *     {
     423             :  *       T value;
     424             :  *       Tree<T>* left;
     425             :  *       Tree<T>* right;
     426             :  *     };
     427             :  *
     428             :  *     template<typename T>
     429             :  *     using Tree = Variant<Leaf, Node<T>>;
     430             :  *
     431             :  * A copy-on-write string is either a non-owning reference to some existing
     432             :  * string, or an owning reference to our copy:
     433             :  *
     434             :  *     class CopyOnWriteString
     435             :  *     {
     436             :  *       Variant<const char*, UniquePtr<char[]>> string;
     437             :  *
     438             :  *       ...
     439             :  *     };
     440             :  *
     441             :  * Because Variant must be aligned suitable to hold any value stored within it,
     442             :  * and because |alignas| requirements don't affect platform ABI with respect to
     443             :  * how parameters are laid out in memory, Variant can't be used as the type of a
     444             :  * function parameter.  Pass Variant to functions by pointer or reference
     445             :  * instead.
     446             :  */
     447             : template<typename... Ts>
     448             : class MOZ_INHERIT_TYPE_ANNOTATIONS_FROM_TEMPLATE_ARGS MOZ_NON_PARAM Variant
     449             : {
     450             :   static_assert(detail::TypesAreDistinct<Ts...>::value,
     451             :                 "Variant with duplicate types is not supported");
     452             : 
     453             :   using Tag = typename detail::VariantTag<Ts...>::Type;
     454             :   using Impl = detail::VariantImplementation<Tag, 0, Ts...>;
     455             : 
     456             :   static constexpr size_t RawDataAlignment = tl::Max<alignof(Ts)...>::value;
     457             :   static constexpr size_t RawDataSize = tl::Max<sizeof(Ts)...>::value;
     458             : 
     459             :   // Raw storage for the contained variant value.
     460             :   alignas(RawDataAlignment) unsigned char rawData[RawDataSize];
     461             : 
     462             :   // Each type is given a unique tag value that lets us keep track of the
     463             :   // contained variant value's type.
     464             :   Tag tag;
     465             : 
     466             :   // Some versions of GCC treat it as a -Wstrict-aliasing violation (ergo a
     467             :   // -Werror compile error) to reinterpret_cast<> |rawData| to |T*|, even
     468             :   // through |void*|.  Placing the latter cast in these separate functions
     469             :   // breaks the chain such that affected GCC versions no longer warn/error.
     470             :   void* ptr() {
     471      573987 :     return rawData;
     472             :   }
     473             : 
     474             :   const void* ptr() const {
     475      194545 :     return rawData;
     476             :   }
     477             : 
     478             : public:
     479             :   /** Perfect forwarding construction for some variant type T. */
     480             :   template<typename RefT,
     481             :            // RefT captures both const& as well as && (as intended, to support
     482             :            // perfect forwarding), so we have to remove those qualifiers here
     483             :            // when ensuring that T is a variant of this type, and getting T's
     484             :            // tag, etc.
     485             :            typename T = typename detail::SelectVariantType<RefT, Ts...>::Type>
     486          15 :   explicit Variant(RefT&& aT)
     487      205656 :     : tag(Impl::template tag<T>())
     488             :   {
     489      411312 :     ::new (KnownNotNull, ptr()) T(Forward<RefT>(aT));
     490          15 :   }
     491             : 
     492             :   /**
     493             :    * Constructs this Variant from an AsVariantTemporary<T> such that T can be
     494             :    * stored in one of the types allowable in this Variant. This is used in the
     495             :    * implementation of AsVariant().
     496             :    */
     497             :   template<typename RefT,
     498             :            typename T = typename detail::SelectVariantType<RefT, Ts...>::Type>
     499           0 :   MOZ_IMPLICIT Variant(detail::AsVariantTemporary<RefT>&& aValue)
     500          60 :     : tag(Impl::template tag<T>())
     501             :   {
     502         120 :     ::new (KnownNotNull, ptr()) T(Move(aValue.mValue));
     503           0 :   }
     504             : 
     505             :   /** Copy construction. */
     506          25 :   Variant(const Variant& aRhs)
     507      107599 :     : tag(aRhs.tag)
     508             :   {
     509      107599 :     Impl::copyConstruct(ptr(), aRhs);
     510          25 :   }
     511             : 
     512             :   /** Move construction. */
     513        2145 :   Variant(Variant&& aRhs)
     514      104355 :     : tag(aRhs.tag)
     515             :   {
     516      205064 :     Impl::moveConstruct(ptr(), Move(aRhs));
     517        2145 :   }

     520          25 :   Variant& operator=(const Variant& aRhs) {
     521             :     MOZ_ASSERT(&aRhs != this, "self-assign disallowed");
     522             :     this->~Variant();
     523       28211 :     ::new (KnownNotNull, this) Variant(aRhs);
     524          25 :     return *this;

     628             : 
     629             : /*
     630             :  * AsVariant() is used to construct a Variant<T,...> value containing the
     631             :  * provided T value using type inference. It can be used to construct Variant
     632             :  * values in expressions or return them from functions without specifying the
     633             :  * entire Variant type.
     634             :  *
     635             :  * Because AsVariant() must copy or move the value into a temporary and this
     636             :  * cannot necessarily be elided by the compiler, it's mostly appropriate only
     637             :  * for use with primitive or very small types.
     638             :  *
     639             :  * AsVariant() returns a AsVariantTemporary value which is implicitly
     640             :  * convertible to any Variant that can hold a value of type T.
     641             :  */
     642             : template<typename T>
     643             : detail::AsVariantTemporary<T>
     644             : AsVariant(T&& aValue)
     645             : {
     646          60 :   return detail::AsVariantTemporary<T>(Forward<T>(aValue));
     647             : }
